elements.content: Three new cadmium­(II) tartratoborates, namely, Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8·3H2O (1), K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3), have been successfully synthesized by the hydrothermal method. Compounds 1–3 belong to centric C2/c, acentric Pc, and the polar C2, respectively. Through based on the same hybrid borate–tartrate [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions, they exhibit different structures. The [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion is composed of two tartrate anions and a B­(OH)4 – unit. Compound 1 features a novel 3D network formed by 2D {Cd3[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2}4– anionic layers and [Cd2O10] dimers, forming tunnels of large 14-MRs which are filled by the non-coordination water molecules. Compound 2 has a characteristic 3D network based on {Cd2[(C4H2O6)2B]}− units interlinked via carboxylate groups, forming tunnels of 11-MRs, half of which stuffed with the K+ ions. Compound 3 features 2D {Cd4[(C4H2O6)4B]}3+ layers which are separated by K/Li ions. Luminescent studies suggest that they emit blue light. Compounds 2 and 3 display phase-matchable second harmonic generation signs of about 3.2× and 1.5× KH2PO4, respectively.

elements.content: Three new cadmium tartratoborates have been reported. They feature three different structural types based on the same hybrid borate−tartrate motifs [(C4H2O6)2B]5−. All three compounds are able to emit blue light. More interestingly, compounds 2 and 3 exhibit moderate and strong second harmonic generation responses of 3.2 and 1.5× KH2PO4, respectively.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal borates are a class of significant second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) materials. Among them, β-BaB2O4, LiB3O5, CsLiB6O10, and KBe2BO3F2  have been widely used. Generally, an outstanding second-order NLO material should include acentric structure, large second harmonic generation (SHG) response, moderate birefringence, a wide spectral transparency, non-hygroscopicity, and easiness for crystal growth.

elements.content: To target acentric material, numerous synthetic methods were found such as molecular self-assembling, metal–ligand coordination, and incorporating chiral organic molecules. We reported the first lanthanide borate–acetates, Ln2(CH3CO2)2[B5O9(OH)]·H2O (Ln = La, Ce, and Pr) with interesting SHG properties. Beside acetate, some other organic ligands for instance l-arginine, l-glutamic, tartaric, and citric acid have also been successfully introduced into borate systems. Tartaric acid displays good conformational flexibility and diverse coordination modes. Pan’s group has introduced alkaline earth metal into the alkali metal tartratoborates which led to the discovery of ASr­[C4H2O6B­(OH)2]·4H2O­(A = NH4 +, K+, and Rb+) with SHG responses of about 1.5, 1.5, and 1.7× KH2PO4 (KDP), respectively. In these tartraborates, a novel ligand is condensed by the B­(OH)4 – group and tartrate anion. Our group has successfully synthesized two novel tartratoborates, namely, K2[(C4H2O6)­(B3O4H)]­(H2O) and KCu2[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2.5. The different hybrid borate–tartrate motifs lead to different kinds of structures. Different from ASr­[C4H2O6B­(OH)2]·4H2O (A = NH4 +, K+, and Rb+), in K2[(C4H2O6)­(B3O4H)]­(H2O), a different tartratoborate ligand, namely, [(C4H2O6)2(B3O4H)2]4–, were condensed with two (B3O8H)6– groups and two tartrate anions into.

elements.content: To date, only six metal tartratoborates, namely, KMn2[(L-C4H2O6)2B]·3H2O, ASr­[C4H2O6B­(OH)2]·4H2O (A = NH4 +, K+, Rb+), K2[(C4H2O6) (B3O4H)]­(H2O), and KCu2[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2.5, have been reported. Research studies on transition-metal tartratoborates are still rare. Transition-metal ion with d10 electronic configuration such as Cd2+ is susceptible to large polarizations, and their compounds are able to possess good physical and chemical properties. Hence, we try to introduce Cd2+ into the tartratoborate system. It is hoped that synergistic effects of the highly polarizable Cd2+ ion and the π-conjugate of tartrate anions can result in new NCS materials with excellent NLO properties. Our research efforts afforded three new cadmium­(II) tartratoborates, namely, Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2­(H2O)8·3H2O (1), K2Cd4­[(C4H2O6)2B]2­(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5­[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3). Compounds 2 and 3 exhibit moderate and strong SHG responses. Their syntheses, structures, and SHG properties are described in this report.

elements.content: Cd­(AC)2·H2O (Aladdin, ≥99.0%), LiAc·2H2O (Aladdin, ≥99.0%), K2C4H4O6·4H2O (Aladdin, 99.8%), and H3BO3 (Aladdin, 99.8%) were purchased. All chemicals were used as received. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected in the 2θ range of 5°–70° with a step size of 0.02° on a Panalytical X’pert Pro MPD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation. A field emission scanning electron microscope (JSM6700F) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscope (Oxford INCA) was used for microprobe elemental analyses. In the range of 4000–400 cm–1, IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets. At room temperature, a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer was used to measure the UV–vis–NIR optical diffuse reflectance spectra. A BaSO4 plate was used as a standard (100% reflectance). The Kubelka–Munk function F(R) = (1 – R)2/2R = α/S was used for the calculation of the absorption (α/S) data from the reflectance spectra, where α is the absorption coefficient, R is the reflectance, and S is the scattering coefficient which is practically wavelength independent when the particle size is larger than 5 μm. According to the intercept by extrapolating the straightest line to the hν axis in the α/S versus hν plot, the band gaps were calculated. Under nitrogen atmosphere, a NETZSCH STA449C instrument was used to simultaneously measure thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. Using an Ultima 2 simultaneous inductively coupled plasma (ICP) optical emission spectrometer, the ICP elemental analyses on Li, K, Cd, and B were performed. A German Elementary Vario EL III instrument was used to perform the elemental analyses on C and H elements. By the modified method of Kurtz and Perry, the measurements of the powder frequency-doubling effect were measured. At 1064 nm laser radiation, measurements were carried out for visible SHG. The references for assuming SHG signals were taken sieved KDP samples (150–210 μm). To check whether they were phase-matching, the samples were ground and sieved into several distinct particle size ranges (25–45, 45–53, 53–75, 75–105, 105–150, 150–210, and 210–300 μm). An Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer was used for the studies of photoluminescence in room temperature.

elements.content: Compounds 1–3 were synthesized with similar procedures by a hydrothermal method. The loaded reactive mixtures were Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (2 mmol, 533.06 mg), H3BO3 (3 mmol, 185.49 mg), K2C4H4O6·4H2O (2 mmol, 452.6 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 1; Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (1 mmol, 266.53 mg), H3BO3 (1.5 mmol, 92.7 mg), K2C4H4O6·4H2O (1 mmol, 226.3 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 2; and Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (1 mmol, 266.53 mg), LiAc·2H2O (2 mmol, 204.0 mg), H3BO3 (1 mmol, 61.8 mg), K2C4H4O6·2H2O (2 mmol, 452.6 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 3. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 mL) and then heated at 140 °C for 6 days for compounds 1–3. After cooling to 25 °C, the products were rinsed with deionized water and plate-, prism-, and block-shaped single crystals were obtained. The yields were 80, 65, and 55% based on Cd of compounds 1–3, respectively. Anal. Calcd for Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8·3H2O (1) (Mr = 1366.02): Cd, 41.14%; B, 1.58%; C, 14.06; H, 2.20%. Found: Cd, 41.61%; B, 1.41%; C, 13.87; H, 2.31%. Anal. Calcd for K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) (Mr = 1169.68): K, 6.68%; Cd, 38.44%; B, 1.85%; C, 16.41; H, 1.02%. Found: K, 6.59%; Cd, 37.92%; B, 1.58%; C, 16.42; H, 1.10%. Anal. Calcd for Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3) (Mr = 556.07): Li, 1.15%; K, 7.60%; Cd, 30.32%; B, 1.94%; C, 17.26; H, 1.44%. Found: Li, 1.13%; K, 6.87%; Cd, 30.86%; B, 1.88%; C, 16.78; H, 1.44%. The experimental powder XRD curves of the pure phases were in good match with those simulated from their single-crystal data (Figure S1).

Compounds 1-3 were synthesized with similar procedures by a hydrothermal method. The loaded reactive mixtures were Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (2 mmol, 533.06 mg), H3BO3 (3 mmol, 185.49 mg), K2C4H4O6⋅4H2O (2 mmol, 452.6 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 1; Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (1 mmol, 266.53 mg), H3BO3 (1.5 mmol, 92.7 mg), K2C4H4O6⋅4H2O (1 mmol, 226.3 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 2; and Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (1 mmol, 266.53 mg), LiAc⋅2H2O (2 mmol, 204.0 mg), H3BO3 (1 mmol, 61.8 mg), K2C4H4O6⋅2H2O (2 mmol, 452.6 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 3. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 mL) and then heated at 140 °C for 6 days for compounds 1-3. After cooling to 25 °C, the products were rinsed with deionized water and plate-, prism-, and block-shaped single crystals were obtained. The yields were 80, 65, and 55% based on Cd of compounds 1-3, respectively. Anal. Calcd for Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8⋅3H2O (1) (Mr = 1366.02): Cd, 41.14%; B, 1.58%; C, 14.06; H, 2.20%. Found: Cd, 41.61%; B, 1.41%; C, 13.87; H, 2.31%. Anal. Calcd for K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) (Mr = 1169.68): K, 6.68%; Cd, 38.44%; B, 1.85%; C, 16.41; H, 1.02%. Found: K, 6.59%; Cd, 37.92%; B, 1.58%; C, 16.42; H, 1.10%. Anal. Calcd for Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B](H2O)2 (3) (Mr = 556.07): Li, 1.15%; K, 7.60%; Cd, 30.32%; B, 1.94%; C, 17.26; H, 1.44%. elements.content: The crystal structure of Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8·3H2O (1), K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3) was collected by using a SuperNova Dual Wavelength CCD diffractometer with a monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 273 K. All three datasets and absorption were corrected by the Lorentz and polarization factors and a multiscan method. On the basis of full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 using SHELX-97, the structures of the three compounds were solved by using the direct method and refined. O­(6w) in compound 1 is considered to be disordered over two symmetry-related positions with a short O···O contact (2.32 Å); hence, its occupancy factor was reduced to 50%. All of the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The K(1) and K(2) sites in compound 3 are mixed with Li(1) and Li(2), respectively. The ICP data indicate the presence of Li and K in an average molar ratio of 1:1, which agrees well with the single-crystal refinements. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon atoms were refined with isotropic thermal parameters and located at geometrically calculated positions. Except for the H-atoms associated with O­(6w) in compound 1, the H-atoms associated with water molecules in compounds 1–3 were included in the final refinements. The Flack factor is refined to be −0.09(3) for compound 2 and −0.02(3) for compound 3, indicating the correctness of their absolute structures. For checking the correctness of the space group adopted by these compounds, the program PLATON was applied. Crystallographic data and selected bond lengths are listed in and Table S1 (Supporting Information).

The crystal structure of Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8⋅3H2O (1), K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B](H2O)2 (3) was collected by using a SuperNova Dual Wavelength CCD diffractometer with a monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 273 K. O(6w) in compound 1 is considered to be disordered over two symmetry-related positions with a short O⋅⋅⋅O contact (2.32 Å); hence, its occupancy factor was reduced to 50%. All of the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The K(1) and K(2) sites in compound 3 are mixed with Li(1) and Li(2), respectively. The ICP data indicate the presence of Li and K in an average molar ratio of 1:1, which agrees well with the single-crystal refinements. Theoretical calculations of K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3) have been performed. By using a first-principles plane-wave pseudopotential technique based on density functional theory within the computer code of CASTEP, the electronic structures and optical property calculations were performed. The generalized gradient approximation-Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof is chosen as the exchange–correlation function in the calculations. The electron–core interactions were treated by Norm-conserving pseudopotential. The outmost electrons of B, C, O, Li, and H, as well as K 3s23p64s1 and Cd 4d105s2 were considered as valence electrons. To determine the numerical integration and plane-wave numbers, A 2 × 3 × 2 k-point sampling and a 750 eV cutoff energy were adopted. To make the SHG coefficients effectively converge, there are more than 600 empty bands were contained in the optical property calculations. We adopted the static formula put forward by Lin which has been proven to be more accurate by numerous previous reports for treating the borates for the calculation of second-order NLO susceptibilities.

Computational Description

Theoretical calculations of K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B](H2O)2 (3) have been performed. By using a first-principles plane-wave pseudopotential technique based on density functional theory within the computer code of CASTEP, the electronic structures and optical property calculations were performed. The generalized gradient approximation-Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof is chosen as the exchange-correlation function in the calculations. The electron-core interactions were treated by Norm-conserving pseudopotential. The outmost electrons of B, C, O, Li, and H, as well as K 3s23p64s1 and Cd 4d105s2 were considered as valence electrons. To determine the numerical integration and plane-wave numbers, A 2 × 3 × 2 k-point sampling and a 750 eV cutoff energy were adopted. To make the SHG coefficients effectively converge, there are more than 600 empty bands were contained in the optical property calculations. We adopted the static formula put forward by Lin which has been proven to be more accurate by numerous previous reports for treating the borates for the calculation of second-order NLO susceptibilities.

elements.content: Three new cadmium­(II) tartratoborates, namely, Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2­(H2O)8·3H2O (1), K2Cd4­[(C4H2O6)2B]2­(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5­[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3), have been prepared by the hydrothermal method. Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized with the same reactant in different ratios, whereas compound 3 was prepared by adding more LiAc·H2O. In these three compounds, one BO4 and two tartrate anions are covalently bonded into a [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion (), such a tartratoborate anion has also been observed in KCu2[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2.5. The four carboxylate groups are available for metal coordination. These [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions are bridged by metal centers into three different 3D structures.

Results and Discussion

Three new cadmium(II) tartratoborates, namely, Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8⋅3H2O (1), K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B](H2O)2 (3), have been prepared by the hydrothermal method. Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized with the same reactant in different ratios, whereas compound 3 was prepared by adding more LiAc⋅H2O. In these three compounds, one BO4 and two tartrate anions are covalently bonded into a [(C4H2O6)2B]5- anion (), such a tartratoborate anion has also been observed in KCu2[(C4H2O6)2B](H2O)2.5. The four carboxylate groups are available for metal coordination. These [(C4H2O6)2B]5- anions are bridged by metal centers into three different 3D structures.

elements.content: Cd5[(C4H2O6)­B]2(H2O)8·3H2O­(1) with C2/c symmetry demonstrated a special 3D network composed of 2D {Cd3[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2}4– anionic layers with [Cd2O10] dimers as interlayer linkers (). There are two Cd2+ ions in the general sites and one Cd2+ ion lying on a twofold rotation axis, one [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion, and seven water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. Cd(1) lying on a twofold rotation axis is eight-coordinated by two [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions in tetradentate chelating fashion (Figure S2a). Cd(2) is surrounded by a [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion in a bidentate chelating mode, two additional carboxylate oxygens from two other [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions, and two aqua ligands (Figure S2b). Cd(3) is eight-coordinated by a [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion in tetradentate chelating fashion, a bidentate chelating −COOH group from another [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion, and two aqua ligands (Figure S2c). The Cd–O distances are in the range of 2.246(7)–2.804(8) Å, which are similar to other reported compounds. The four-coordinated B atom has B–O distances within 1.460(11)–1.479(11) Å, being approximated to those reported in other borates. The BO4 groups are embedded with two tartrate anions and give a [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion (a).

Cd(3) is seven-coordinated by one [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion in tetradentate chelating fashion, one bidentate chelating, and one unidentate carboxylate groups from two other [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions (Figure S3d). As in compound 1, the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions are formed by BO4 groups and chiral tartarate anions (Figure S3d,e). These bond distances are quite normal.

elements.content: Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3) belongs to chiral C2, and its structure features 2D {Cd4[(C4H2O6)4B]}− layers (). Its asymmetric unit contains two Li+ ions, two K+ ions, two Cd2+ ions, one [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion, and two aqua ligands. The K(1) and K(2) sites are mixed with Li in a K/Li molar ratio of 0.63:0.37 and 0.45:0.55, respectively. The M(1) is eightfold coordination with six oxygens from four tartratoborate ligands and an aqua ligand (Figure S4b), whereas the M(2) atom is bonded to four oxygens from two tartratoborate ligands and three aqua ligands (Figure S4c). The range of K/Li–O distances is 2.736(6)–3.113(7) Å. Cd(1) is eight-coordinated by two [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions in a tetradentate chelating mode (Figure S3d). Cd(2) is eight-coordinated by one [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion in a tetradentate chelating style, a bidentate chelating −COOH group from another [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion, and two aqua ligands (Figure S3d). The Cd–O distances are in the range of 2.282(6)–2.623(5) Å. The B–O distances are within 1.455(6)–1.478(7) Å. In a way similar to that in compounds 1 and 2, [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions are created. All of these bond distance values are in normal range.

elements.content: In these three compounds, a [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion is formed by condensation of a BO4 group with two tartrate anions (). Compared the coordination geometries of metals and [(C4H2O6)2B]5– in these three compounds, there are some similarities and differences. Similarly, each [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion connects with two Cd2+ ions in a tetradentate chelating fashion to form {Cd2[(C4H2O6)2B]}− anions in compounds 1–3. These {Cd2[(C4H2O6)2B]}− anions are able to further interconnect to form 2D layers (1 and 3) or 3D networks (for 2) through bridging carboxylate groups. The 2D layers are divided by K/Li cations in 3 or further interconnected by Cd2O10 dimers into a 3D network in 1. The number of aqua ligands present also has a strong effect on the structures of the compounds as they change the coordination sites of center metals available for the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– ligand; hence, the coordination mode of the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– ligand is adjusted accordingly. In compound 1, the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– ligand connects with Cd1 and Cd3 in a tetradentate fashion, another Cd3 by using a bidentate chelating carboxylate group (O5–C5–O6) and one Cd2 bidentately by using two carboxylate oxygens (O2 and O4), two additional Cd2 ions in a unidentate fashion (a). In compound 2, the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– ligand connects with 6 Cd2+ ions and 4 K+ ions (b), whereas in compound 3, the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– ligand connects with 3 Cd2+ ions and 7 K+/Li+ mixed sites (c). Hence, the [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anion is a very flexible ligand that can adopt a variety of coordination modes.

elements.content: In addition, the size of the cations maybe effect on the structures and centricity. In compound 1, around their coordination environment, the Cd2+ cations can interact with more polyhedra. For more effective packing, the interacting polyhedral is line up in an antiparallel manner, which results in a centrosymmetric structure. In contrast, a noncentrosymmetric structure of compounds 2 and 3 can be resulted by the introduction of K+ and Li+ cations. The alignment of the coordinating polyhedral around the K+ and Li+ cations leads to the construction of the backbone in a confined space. Thus, the NCS structure is formed. By changing the bonding nature of the constituent polyhedra, the size of the templating cations influences the framework structures and the centricity as well. Compared to the 3D network for compound 2, adding more Li+ resulted in a 2D layer network for compound 3.

elements.content: TGA and DSC curves of compounds 1–3 are presented in Figure S5. The weight loss between 70 and 300 °C in 1 corresponds to the loss of 16.0 H2O (Figure S5a). The observed weight loss matches with the calculated ones (14.60% vs 15.60%). The weight loss between 300 and 600 °C can be assigned to the further decomposition of compound, which is also supported by its DSC curves. The peak around 100 °C goes to the release of H2O molecules, whereas the sharp exothermic peaks at 400 °C are equivalent to the inflammation of the organic units. TGA experiments revealed that compounds 2 and 3 can be stabilized to 126 and 152 °C, respectively, and then they display two steps of weight losses (Figure S5b,c). The small weight losses at 126–280 °C for compound 2 and 152–346 °C for compound 3 correspond to the release of aqua ligands. The observed weight losses (5.30 and 8.18% for compounds 2 and 3, respectively) are near to the calculated ones (about 3.07 and 6.47%). The second step covering 280–650 and 346–650 °C for compounds 2 and 3 corresponds to the burning of the organic groups, which also agrees with their DSC curves. Upon calcination, compounds 1–3 transform into amorphous materials.

TGA and DSC Studies

TGA and DSC curves of compounds 1-3 are presented in Figure S5. The weight loss between 70 and 300 °C in 1 corresponds to the loss of 16.0 H2O (Figure S5a). The observed weight loss matches with the calculated ones (14.60% vs 15.60%). The weight loss between 300 and 600 °C can be assigned to the further decomposition of compound, which is also supported by its DSC curves. The peak around 100 °C goes to the release of H2O molecules, whereas the sharp exothermic peaks at 400 °C are equivalent to the inflammation of the organic units. TGA experiments revealed that compounds 2 and 3 can be stabilized to 126 and 152 °C, respectively, and then they display two steps of weight losses (Figure S5b,c). The small weight losses at 126-280 °C for compound 2 and 152-346 °C for compound 3 correspond to the release of aqua ligands. The observed weight losses (5.30 and 8.18% for compounds 2 and 3, respectively) are near to the calculated ones (about 3.07 and 6.47%). The second step covering 280-650 and 346-650 °C for compounds 2 and 3 corresponds to the burning of the organic groups, which also agrees with their DSC curves. Upon calcination, compounds 1-3 transform into amorphous materials.

elements.content:
Compounds 1–3 are wide band gap semiconductors with optical band gaps of 5.31, 5.45, and 5.40 eV, respectively (Figure S6); hence, their UV cutoff edges are at 233, 227, and 229 nm, respectively.

All compounds display broad absorption peaks centering at 3541 and 3339 cm–1 associated with water molecules. The bands from 2875 to 2959 cm–1 are originated by C–H stretching vibrations. Absorption bands from 1223 to 1594 cm–1 could be ascribed to the asymmetric stretching of CO and C–O. The bands around 962–1087 and 709–816 cm–1 are due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching of B–O, respectively. The peaks at 521, 527, and 529 cm–1 come from B–O deformation vibrations (Figure S7).

UV and IR Spectra

Compounds 1-3 are wide band gap semiconductors with optical band gaps of 5.31, 5.45, and 5.40 eV, respectively (Figure S6); hence, their UV cutoff edges are at 233, 227, and 229 nm, respectively.

All compounds display broad absorption peaks centering at 3541 and 3339 cm-1 associated with water molecules. The bands from 2875 to 2959 cm-1 are originated by C-H stretching vibrations. Absorption bands from 1223 to 1594 cm-1 could be ascribed to the asymmetric stretching of CO and C-O. The bands around 962-1087 and 709-816 cm-1 are due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching of B-O, respectively. The peaks at 521, 527, and 529 cm-1 come from B-O deformation vibrations (Figure S7).

elements.content: It is worth examining the SHG properties of compounds 2 and 3 because they crystallize in the chiral space group Pc and C2, respectively. The results of SHG measurements indicate that compounds 2 and 3 exhibit SHG responses of 3.2 and 1.5× KDP, respectively, and both are phase-matchable (). Compared to ASr­[C4H2O6B­(OH)2]·4H2O (A = NH4 +, K+, and Rb+), compound 2 exhibits a much larger SHG effect. In order to better understand the structure–property relationships in compounds 2 and 3, the local dipole moments for CdO x (x = 6, 7, and 8) and BO4 groups as well as the unit cell net dipole moments were calculated (Table S2). The local dipole moments of the CdO x (x = 6, 7, and 8) and BO4 units were calculated to be 6.47, 6.23, 8.39, 6.83, 0.43, and 0.51 D for compound 2. The y components have been canceled out completely, whereas the x and z components amount to 5.81 and 6.02 D for compound 2, respectively. The unit cell dipole moment is 8.51 D. The local dipole moments of the CdO8 and BO4 units are 6.10, 8.68, and 0.48 D for compound 3. Only the components of the polarization along the polar b axis add up in the unit cell, resulting in a net dipole moment of 22.95 D. Such small net dipole moments imply that the carboxylate groups in compounds 2 and 3 also contribute to their strong SHG responses observed.
elements.clean_text:
SHG Properties

It is worth examining the SHG properties of compounds 2 and 3 because they crystallize in the chiral space group Pc and C2, respectively. The results of SHG measurements indicate that compounds 2 and 3 exhibit SHG responses of 3.2 and 1.5× KDP, respectively, and both are phase-matchable (). Compared to ASr[C4H2O6B(OH)2]⋅4H2O (A = NH4 +, K+, and Rb+), compound 2 exhibits a much larger SHG effect. In order to better understand the structure-property relationships in compounds 2 and 3, the local dipole moments for CdO x  (x = 6, 7, and 8) and BO4 groups as well as the unit cell net dipole moments were calculated (Table S2). The local dipole moments of the CdO x  (x = 6, 7, and 8) and BO4 units were calculated to be 6.47, 6.23, 8.39, 6.83, 0.43, and 0.51 D for compound 2. The y components have been canceled out completely, whereas the x and z components amount to 5.81 and 6.02 D for compound 2, respectively. The unit cell dipole moment is 8.51 D. The local dipole moments of the CdO8 and BO4 units are 6.10, 8.68, and 0.48 D for compound 3. Only the components of the polarization along the polar b axis add up in the unit cell, resulting in a net dipole moment of 22.95 D. Such small net dipole moments imply that the carboxylate groups in compounds 2 and 3 also contribute to their strong SHG responses observed.

elements.content: To clearly represent the intrinsic relationship between the SHG effects and the crystal structures, the theoretical investigations on compounds 2 and 3 were performed. The DOS graphs are presented in . It is found that the partial density of states of all kinds of atoms and orbitals are very similar to each other for the two compounds because of their similar geometric structures, so we take K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) as a representative. For compound 2 (a), the electronic states of C, B, and Cd atoms are fully overlapped with those of O atoms from VB to CB, implying the strong C–O, B–O, and Cd–O bond interactions. There are two kinds of C atoms, 1,4-C (carboxylic C) and 2,3-C (methine C), which exhibit very different bonding characteristics with O atoms. The peaks at −4.8 and 6.1 eV are corresponding to the π bonding and π* antibonding of 1,4-C and O atoms, respectively. The VB peaks near the Fermi level are mainly the nonbonding states of O atoms and σ bonding states among the 2,3-C atoms, with small amount of σ bonding states between the 1,4-C atoms and the 2,3-C atoms mixed at the highest VB. We can also see that the lowest conduction bands are originated from the π* antibonding of 1,4-C and O atoms. Therefore, the band gap of compound 2 is determined by the tartaric acid anions.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

To clearly represent the intrinsic relationship between the SHG effects and the crystal structures, the theoretical investigations on compounds 2 and 3 were performed. The DOS graphs are presented in . It is found that the partial density of states of all kinds of atoms and orbitals are very similar to each other for the two compounds because of their similar geometric structures, so we take K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) as a representative. For compound 2 (a), the electronic states of C, B, and Cd atoms are fully overlapped with those of O atoms from VB to CB, implying the strong C-O, B-O, and Cd-O bond interactions. There are two kinds of C atoms, 1,4-C (carboxylic C) and 2,3-C (methine C), which exhibit very different bonding characteristics with O atoms. The peaks at -4.8 and 6.1 eV are corresponding to the π bonding and π* antibonding of 1,4-C and O atoms, respectively. The VB peaks near the Fermi level are mainly the nonbonding states of O atoms and σ bonding states among the 2,3-C atoms, with small amount of σ bonding states between the 1,4-C atoms and the 2,3-C atoms mixed at the highest VB. We can also see that the lowest conduction bands are originated from the π* antibonding of 1,4-C and O atoms. Therefore, the band gap of compound 2 is determined by the tartaric acid anions.

elements.content: K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2­(H2O)2 (2) and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5­[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3) crystallize in Pc and C2, respectively. For the monoclinic system, the principal axis transformation must be made before the optical property calculations. On the basis of the formula reported previously, the rotation angles of compounds 2 and 3 are calculated to be 0.601° and 44.252°, respectively. Considering the Kleinman symmetry, compounds 2 and 3 have six and four independent SHG tensors, respectively. The highest SHG tensors in the static limit are calculated to be 3.48 × 10–9 and 1.64 × 10–9 esu for d 31 of compound 2 and d 22 of compound 3, respectively (Table S3). The calculated SHG effects come near our measured values (∼3.2 and 1.5 times that of KDP for compounds 2 and 3, respectively). Meanwhile, the refractive indices of compounds 2 and 3 were also calculated (). The magnitudes of refractive indices follow the sequences of n x > n y > n z and n y > n z > n x in 0–3 eV for compounds 2 and 3, respectively. The calculated birefringences at 1064 nm are 0.111 and 0.051, for compounds 2 and 3, respectively; phase matching in SHG process can be easily achieved.

For the monoclinic system, the principal axis transformation must be made before the optical property calculations. On the basis of the formula reported previously, the rotation angles of compounds 2 and 3 are calculated to be 0.601° and 44.252°, respectively. Considering the Kleinman symmetry, compounds 2 and 3 have six and four independent SHG tensors, respectively. The highest SHG tensors in the static limit are calculated to be 3.48 × 10-9 and 1.64 × 10-9 esu for d 31 of compound 2 and d 22 of compound 3, respectively (Table S3). The calculated SHG effects come near our measured values (~3.2 and 1.5 times that of KDP for compounds 2 and 3, respectively). Meanwhile, the refractive indices of compounds 2 and 3 were also calculated (). The magnitudes of refractive indices follow the sequences of n  x  > n  y  > n  z  and n  y  > n  z  > n  x  in 0-3 eV for compounds 2 and 3, respectively. elements.content: The spectral decompositions of the highest SHG tensors d 31 for compound 2 and d 22 for compound 3 were performed to reveal the SHG-contributed energy levels. As shown in , it is found that for d 31 of compound 2, the upper part of VB (−3.3 to 0 eV) and the lower part of CB (<7.5 eV) give the most contributions to SHG, and for the above-mentioned regions in PDOS graphs, the O 2p nonbonding states, the 2,3-C 2p states, and the π* antibonding states between 1,4-C and O atoms dominate. Similarly for d 22 of compound 3, the major and positive SHG contributions are still from the upper part of VB (−4.7 to 0 eV) and the lower part of CB (<10.4 eV), but the regions of −7.4 to −6.9 and 10.4–13.1 eV give some negative contributions to SHG. To accurately and intuitively exhibit the SHG-contributed atoms and electronic states, SHG density was calculated and is displayed in . For d 31 of compound 2, in VB, the 2p nonbonding states of all O atoms contribute the SHG dominantly; in CB, the π* antibonding states of 1,4-C and O atoms give the most contributions to SHG. The case of compound 3 is more complicated. For d 22 in VB, the main contributions come from the 2p nonbonding states of O atoms bonded with carboxylic C1 and C5, whereas a bit of 2p states of terminal O atoms bonded to carboxylic C8 contribute negatively, which weaken the SHG response to some extent. In CB, the π* antibonding states of some carboxylic C atoms (C4 and C8) and their bonded O atoms are the most predominant contributors to SHG. Summing up the above-mentioned analyses, we can clearly find that the tartaric acid anions play most important parts in contributing the SHG responses of compounds 2 and 3.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent properties of compounds 1–3 were measured at room temperature (). Compounds 1–3 emit blue luminescence. Compounds 1 and 2 show two broad emission bands at about 445 and 468 nm when excited at 360 nm, respectively, whereas compound 3 shows an emission maximum at 492 nm under excitation at 419 nm. However, understanding of the luminescence mechanism for metal borates is still limited, and further experimental or theoretical explorations are desired. According to refs and , Cd coordination polymers usually display similar luminescence. We deem that the blue luminescence of 1–3 may be due to the LMCT within the borate framework.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties of compounds 1-3 were measured at room temperature (). Compounds 1-3 emit blue luminescence. Compounds 1 and 2 show two broad emission bands at about 445 and 468 nm when excited at 360 nm, respectively, whereas compound 3 shows an emission maximum at 492 nm under excitation at 419 nm. However, understanding of the luminescence mechanism for metal borates is still limited, and further experimental or theoretical explorations are desired. According to refs  and , Cd coordination polymers usually display similar luminescence. We deem that the blue luminescence of 1-3 may be due to the LMCT within the borate framework.

elements.content: In summary, three new cadmium tartratoborates, namely, Cd5(C8H4O8B)2­(H2O)8·3H2O (1), K2Cd4­[(C4H2O6)2B]2­(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5­[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3), have been obtained and structurally described. Three different structural types based on the same [(C4H2O6)2B]5– anions are formed. Luminescent studies show that compounds 1–3 are able to emit blue light. More interestingly, compounds 2 and 3 display strong NLO coefficients of 3.2 and 1.5× KDP, respectively. It is expected that the SHG performance could be further enhanced if we can introduce cations with lone pair or borate groups containing BO3 groups.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, three new cadmium tartratoborates, namely, Cd5(C8H4O8B)2(H2O)8⋅3H2O (1), K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2), and Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B](H2O)2 (3), have been obtained and structurally described. Three different structural types based on the same [(C4H2O6)2B]5- anions are formed. Luminescent studies show that compounds 1-3 are able to emit blue light. More interestingly, compounds 2 and 3 display strong NLO coefficients of 3.2 and 1.5× KDP, respectively. It is expected that the SHG performance could be further enhanced if we can introduce cations with lone pair or borate groups containing BO3 groups.

cln_elements.content: Compounds 1–3 were synthesized with similar procedures by a hydrothermal method. The loaded reactive mixtures were Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (2 mmol, 533.06 mg), H3BO3 (3 mmol, 185.49 mg), K2C4H4O6·4H2O (2 mmol, 452.6 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 1; Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (1 mmol, 266.53 mg), H3BO3 (1.5 mmol, 92.7 mg), K2C4H4O6·4H2O (1 mmol, 226.3 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 2; and Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (1 mmol, 266.53 mg), LiAc·2H2O (2 mmol, 204.0 mg), H3BO3 (1 mmol, 61.8 mg), K2C4H4O6·2H2O (2 mmol, 452.6 mg), and H2O (3 mL) for compound 3. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (23 mL) and then heated at 140 °C for 6 days for compounds 1–3. After cooling to 25 °C, the products were rinsed with deionized water and plate-, prism-, and block-shaped single crystals were obtained. The yields were 80, 65, and 55% based on Cd of compounds 1–3, respectively. Anal. Calcd for Cd5[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)8·3H2O (1) (Mr = 1366.02): Cd, 41.14%; B, 1.58%; C, 14.06; H, 2.20%. Found: Cd, 41.61%; B, 1.41%; C, 13.87; H, 2.31%. Anal. Calcd for K2Cd4[(C4H2O6)2B]2(H2O)2 (2) (Mr = 1169.68): K, 6.68%; Cd, 38.44%; B, 1.85%; C, 16.41; H, 1.02%. Found: K, 6.59%; Cd, 37.92%; B, 1.58%; C, 16.42; H, 1.10%. Anal. Calcd for Li0.92K1.08Cd1.5[(C4H2O6)2B]­(H2O)2 (3) (Mr = 556.07): Li, 1.15%; K, 7.60%; Cd, 30.32%; B, 1.94%; C, 17.26; H, 1.44%. Found: Li, 1.13%; K, 6.87%; Cd, 30.86%; B, 1.88%; C, 16.78; H, 1.44%. The experimental powder XRD curves of the pure phases were in good match with those simulated from their single-crystal data (Figure S1).

cln_elements.content:
TGA and DSC curves of compounds 1–3 are presented in Figure S5. The weight loss between 70 and 300 °C in 1 corresponds to the loss of 16.0 H2O (Figure S5a). The observed weight loss matches with the calculated ones (14.60% vs 15.60%). The weight loss between 300 and 600 °C can be assigned to the further decomposition of compound, which is also supported by its DSC curves. The peak around 100 °C goes to the release of H2O molecules, whereas the sharp exothermic peaks at 400 °C are equivalent to the inflammation of the organic units. TGA experiments revealed that compounds 2 and 3 can be stabilized to 126 and 152 °C, respectively, and then they display two steps of weight losses (Figure S5b,c). The small weight losses at 126–280 °C for compound 2 and 152–346 °C for compound 3 correspond to the release of aqua ligands. The observed weight losses (5.30 and 8.18% for compounds 2 and 3, respectively) are near to the calculated ones (about 3.07 and 6.47%). The second step covering 280–650 and 346–650 °C for compounds 2 and 3 corresponds to the burning of the organic groups, which also agrees with their DSC curves. Upon calcination, compounds 1–3 transform into amorphous materials.

UV and IR Spectra

Compounds 1–3 are wide band gap semiconductors with optical band gaps of 5.31, 5.45, and 5.40 eV, respectively (Figure S6); hence, their UV cutoff edges are at 233, 227, and 229 nm, respectively.

All compounds display broad absorption peaks centering at 3541 and 3339 cm–1 associated with water molecules. The bands from 2875 to 2959 cm–1 are originated by C–H stretching vibrations. Absorption bands from 1223 to 1594 cm–1 could be ascribed to the asymmetric stretching of CO and C–O. The bands around 962–1087 and 709–816 cm–1 are due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching of B–O, respectively. The peaks at 521, 527, and 529 cm–1 come from B–O deformation vibrations (Figure S7).

Luminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties of compounds 1–3 were measured at room temperature (). Compounds 1–3 emit blue luminescence. Compounds 1 and 2 show two broad emission bands at about 445 and 468 nm when excited at 360 nm, respectively, whereas compound 3 shows an emission maximum at 492 nm under excitation at 419 nm. However, understanding of the luminescence mechanism for metal borates is still limited, and further experimental or theoretical explorations are desired. According to refs and , Cd coordination polymers usually display similar luminescence. We deem that the blue luminescence of 1–3 may be due to the LMCT within the borate framework.
